words.meaning: The right or condition of self-government; freedom from external control or influence.
examples: The region was granted autonomy after a long struggle.
The university values its autonomy from government interference.

words.meaning: Providing supplementary or additional help and support.
examples: The hospital has an auxiliary nursing staff to help during emergencies.
The ship has an auxiliary engine in case the main one fails.

words.meaning: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
examples: His heart was consumed by avarice.
Avarice can lead people to do terrible things.

words.meaning: Having or showing an extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
examples: The avaricious businessman was never satisfied with his profits.
She had an avaricious hunger for power.

words.meaning: To state or assert to be the case.
examples: He averred that he was innocent of the charges.
She averred that she had seen the man leave the building.

words.meaning: Having a strong dislike of or opposition to something.
examples: He is averse to taking unnecessary risks.
She is not averse to a little flattery.

words.meaning: A strong dislike or disinclination.
examples: He has a strong aversion to spiders.
She felt an immediate aversion to the new manager.

words.meaning: To turn away (one's eyes or thoughts); or to prevent or ward off (an undesirable occurrence).
examples: She had to avert her eyes from the gruesome scene.
The government took steps to avert a crisis.

words.meaning: Having or showing a keen interest in or enthusiasm for something.
examples: He is an avid reader of history books.
She is an avid supporter of the local team.

words.meaning: A hobby or minor occupation.
examples: His main avocation is stamp collecting.
She pursued her avocation of painting in her spare time.

words.meaning: To assert or confess openly.
examples: He avowed that he would not rest until he had achieved his goal.
She avowed her love for him in front of everyone.

words.meaning: Kind and friendly toward a younger or less experienced person; relating to an uncle.
examples: He gave the young man some avuncular advice.
The professor had an avuncular relationship with his students.

words.meaning: Extremely impressive or daunting; inspiring great admiration, apprehension, or fear.
examples: The view from the top of the mountain was awesome.
He has an awesome responsibility on his shoulders.

words.meaning: A statement or proposition that is regarded as being established, accepted, or self-evidently true.
examples: It is a well-known axiom that 'actions speak louder than words'.
The book begins with the axiom that all men are created equal.

words.meaning: Self-evident or unquestionable.
examples: It is axiomatic that practice makes perfect.
The axiomatic truth of the statement cannot be denied.

words.meaning: To talk rapidly and continuously in a foolish, excited, or incomprehensible way.
examples: The baby started to babble happily.
He began to babble on about his latest conspiracy theory.

words.meaning: Characterized by or given to drunken revelry; riotously drunken.
examples: The party turned into a bacchanalian frenzy.
He was known for his bacchanalian lifestyle.

words.meaning: To ask (someone) repeatedly and annoyingly for something; pester.
examples: The children kept badgering him to buy them a new toy.
She finally agreed after he had badgered her for weeks.

words.meaning: A thing of little importance; a trifle.
examples: The argument was over a mere bagatelle.
Compared to the big problems we face, this is a bagatelle.

words.meaning: Threatening harm; menacing.
examples: He gave her a baleful look.
The baleful clouds gathered on the horizon.

words.meaning: To hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking.
examples: He balked at the idea of paying so much for a ticket.
The horse balked at the high fence.

words.meaning: To swell out in a spherical shape; to increase rapidly.
examples: The company's debt has ballooned in recent years.
The dress ballooned out in the wind.

words.meaning: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
examples: The movie's plot was banal and predictable.
He made some banal remarks about the weather.

words.meaning: The fact or condition of being banal; unoriginality.
examples: The conversation was full of banalities and clich√©s.
She was struck by the banality of everyday life.

words.meaning: A cause of great distress or annoyance.
examples: The bane of my existence is the constant noise from the construction site.
That child is the bane of my life.

words.meaning: Harmful or destructive.
examples: The baneful influence of the dictator was felt throughout the country.
The baneful effects of the drug were not immediately apparent.

words.meaning: To send (someone) away from a country or place as an official punishment.
examples: The king banished his enemies from the kingdom.
He was banished to a remote island.

words.meaning: The playful and friendly exchange of teasing remarks.
examples: The two friends engaged in some lighthearted banter.
There was a lot of banter and good humor at the party.

words.meaning: A poet, traditionally one reciting epics and associated with a particular oral tradition.
examples: William Shakespeare is often referred to as 'the Bard'.
The ancient bard sang tales of heroes and gods.

words.meaning: Shameless; undisguised.
examples: That was a barefaced lie!
He had the barefaced audacity to ask for more money.

words.meaning: Something that reflects changes in circumstances or opinions.
examples: The stock market is a barometer of economic confidence.
Consumer spending is a good barometer of the country's economic health.

words.meaning: Relating to or denoting a style of European architecture, music, and art of the 17th and 18th centuries that followed mannerism and is characterized by ornate detail.
examples: The church was built in a magnificent baroque style.
He preferred the simple elegance of classical music to the ornate complexity of baroque.

words.meaning: A concentrated artillery bombardment over a wide area.
examples: The city came under a heavy barrage of shelling.
He faced a barrage of questions from the press.

words.meaning: (of land) too poor to produce much or any vegetation.
examples: The barren desert stretched for miles in every direction.
The land was barren and unsuitable for farming.

words.meaning: Without moral principles; ignoble.
examples: It was a base and cowardly act.
He was motivated by base desires.

words.meaning: To lie exposed to warmth and light, typically from the sun, for relaxation and pleasure.
examples: The cat was basking in the sunshine.
He basked in the glory of his victory.

words.meaning: The action of corrupting or debasing something.
examples: Critics called the new movie a bastardization of the original book.
The bastardization of the language is a cause for concern.

words.meaning: A series of similar items.
examples: The lawyer faced a battery of questions from the reporters.
The doctor ordered a battery of tests.

words.meaning: A small, showy trinket or decoration.
examples: The Christmas tree was decorated with colorful baubles.
She spent her money on cheap baubles and trinkets.

words.meaning: Dealing with sexual matters in a comical way; humorously indecent.
examples: The play was full of bawdy humor.
He told a bawdy joke that made everyone laugh.

words.meaning: (of a dog, especially a large one) to bark or howl loudly.
examples: The hounds were baying at the moon.
The crowd was baying for blood.

words.meaning: Feeling or expressing blissful happiness.
examples: She had a beatific smile on her face.
The saint was depicted with a beatific expression.

words.meaning: (especially of clothing or a color) suitable or flattering.
examples: That dress is very becoming on you.
The new hairstyle is very becoming.

words.meaning: A scene of uproar and confusion.
examples: There was bedlam in the streets after the team won the championship.
The classroom was in a state of bedlam.

words.meaning: Unable to think clearly; confused.
examples: He was befuddled by the complex instructions.
The old man was befuddled and didn't know where he was.

words.meaning: To ask (someone) earnestly or humbly for something.
examples: He begged her to forgive him.
The children begged to be allowed to stay up late.

words.meaning: To bring (a child) into existence by the process of reproduction; to give rise to; bring about.
examples: Violence can beget more violence.
In the Bible, Abraham begot Isaac.

words.meaning: To envy (someone) the possession or enjoyment of (something).
examples: I don't begrudge him his success; he's worked hard for it.
She begrudged her sister the attention she received from their parents.

words.meaning: To charm or enchant (someone), sometimes in a deceptive way.
examples: He beguiled her with his smooth talk and charming smile.
She was beguiled into buying the expensive dress.

words.meaning: A huge or monstrous creature or thing.
examples: The new shopping mall is a behemoth of a building.
The company has become a behemoth in the tech industry.

words.meaning: In a difficult or losing position.
examples: After losing the key witness, the prosecution was behind the eight ball.
He's behind the eight ball financially.

words.meaning: It is a duty or responsibility for someone to do something; it is incumbent on.
examples: It behooves us to be prepared for any emergency.
It behooves the team to practice hard before the big game.

words.meaning: To argue or elaborate (a subject) in excessive detail.
examples: There is no need to belabor the point; we all understand.
He kept belaboring his achievements.

words.meaning: Coming or happening later than should have been the case.
examples: He sent her a belated birthday card.
She made a belated apology.

words.meaning: In a very difficult situation.
examples: The beleaguered company is facing bankruptcy.
The beleaguered president is facing calls for his resignation.

words.meaning: The part of a bell tower or steeple in which bells are housed.
examples: The old church had a magnificent belfry.
The expression 'bats in the belfry' means someone is eccentric or crazy.

words.meaning: To fail to give a true notion or impression of (something); disguise or contradict.
examples: His calm demeanor belied his inner turmoil.
Her cheerful smile belied the sadness in her eyes.

words.meaning: Past tense of belie; failed to give a true notion or impression of (something).
examples: His confident words were belied by his nervous gestures.
The initial test results belied the severity of the disease.

words.meaning: To make (someone or something) seem unimportant.
examples: He would always belittle her achievements.
It is not right to belittle the efforts of others.

words.meaning: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
examples: The bellicose politician was always eager for a confrontation.
The country adopted a bellicose stance towards its neighbors.
